review_title: Don't work here if you show compassion to the patients and families
job_title: in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Rewarding job working with children
cons: They can't keep staff. No one is going to work for $15/hr starting and be worked into the ground. Make sure you don't get too close to the patients or the families because if you try to advocate for them you will be fired for insubordination. Doesn't matter if the families come to you directly, if you enter their room without an order for labwork and just try to be a compassionate person, HR will come after you and your department leaders will not stand up for you at all even when you know that you did absolutely nothing wrong. This is the only place I know that will fire one of the top phlebotomists that bends over backwards for their dept for being a kind compassionate person. It doesn't matter how bad this will hurt their team, management has absolutely NO backbone!! Pathetic!!

review_title: Not a place you stay long !
job_title: Senior Certified Pharmacy Technician in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
Able to see the progress of patients and know that you did your very best to help them succeed in treatments while they visited. The children and their families are always very  
appreciative and thankful.
cons: A new employee generates 5-6 hours per pay period. And most full time staff  works  8,10,or 12 hours shifts so that math isn’t matching. HR department isn’t very organized. These people can’t even answer simply questions like salary range. And will do everything to go around it.I have seen them waste countless of applicants time by putting them through the hiring process to offer applicants less than their current rate of pay. Weird bc if you would let them know that info firsthand there wouldn’t be so much time wasted and long vacancies. You would think as much as this hospital generates annually they could offer descent salary so we wouldn’t have such a high turnover. They will require experience and then offer $3 more than minimum wage to external applicants. A lot of times they have already selected someone internal with less experience at the same exact pay point. We had some many good interviewers but most of them feel offended and reject the offers presented. In the past few months, we have lost pharmacy techs, prior auth specialists , and 340B analysts to our competitors. This is just a place you use to get experience and go elsewhere for better pay.

job_title: Rrt in Saint Pete, FL
pros: Some coworkers. Dedicated in the trenched, although having to deal with issues that have no place in a hospital. Worked for Dept. where 25 year director is now gone, to a hospital with the worst reputation in the county (and as a grunt therapist, no longer mgt.). Guess running a professional department like a fraternity house finally caught up to him. Employees who harass, who play games, who hide and avoid work, while others are overwhelmed in the units were covered for since the didn't use sick time (childless men, or "alternative" lifestyle men). Women were treated like 2nd class citizens. Complaints were met with "let's discard the past and go forward, today is a new beginning" yeah, like that made any difference. Post-Sexton CEO began to institute change and I hear John Hopkins has really shaken the place up. Although a few old time managers still need to go.
cons: Having to deal with b.s. that has no place in hospital. Make wages competitive.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Love taking care of children, wished I had more time to care for them.
cons: Always short staffed. Don't approve pto

review_title: Does not follow Evidence Based Care in NICU
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Self scheduling. Your request is usually met unless one of the golden nurses wants it.
cons: The NICU is bigger than they can manage. Too little attention is given to appropriate nurse to neonate assignments and evidence based practice is not being followed. For example: Ampicillin is not supposed to be run through the same line as Dextrose and Amino Acids. TPN is full of Dextrose and Amino Acids and they continue to run them together even when I showed them in Neofax that is was not compatible. There are many more examples. In addition, there is a group of nurses that always get the assignments that they want and never give others the opportunity to get the experience with the more critical patients. Co-workers are rude and there is very little team work. Pumps and alarms would go off all night before another nurse would check on it if it wasn't their assigned baby. Sad....just sad.

review_title: Great Benefits, but my boss is terrible
job_title: Admissions Coordinator in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: The benefits such as Insurance, tuition assistance almost $6,000 a year, tickets to the Rays Baseball Games sometimes are Free, or $35, great company to work for, you can get discounts everywhere for being an employee even if you rent, you can have the move-in deposit waived.
cons: They monitor everything you do! Supervisors nick pick on all the work. They send you error reports daily!!! Actions that need to be corrected. The workload is heavy, no lunch breaks. It's like a slave yard. No one stays there long. They leave as soon as they get a new job. The turnover rate is high and you will have anxiety issues and headaches everyday.

review_title: Unsafe practices regarding excessive floating that is expected of us
job_title: NeoNatal Intensive Care, 33 Yrs Exp in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
Really..none  ...
 I am in the process of resigning...very unsafe
cons: NICU nurses have been staffing the CVICU for ~ 3 mos now....we are NOT trained in this specialty area, yet, we are required to float there shift after shift..taking patients with pacer wires, fresh post-ops, fresh cardiac caths.. They would NEVER allow a new nurse to walk in and take the patients we have to care for,..but somehow, its OK for a NICU nurse. They play by the "a nurse is a nurse is a nurse" rule. One float experience, there were 3 NICU nurses ..all floated to CVIC. My "resourse" was another NICU nurse..??

job_title: Pct in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
-No specific uniforms, you can wear any scrubs or T-shirts/polo shirts you like.
-Pediatric experience
-"John's Hopkins" name on your resume
cons:
-Cliques in every department, if you're not in them you get hung out to dry.
-Management promises changes, brags about firing the problem people, then rehires them 6 months later. Management lies to your face.
-Management tries to tell you to scold your fellow employees for being lazy or calling out.
-No incentive to work in the ER/PICU vs the floor, same rate around the hospital.
-Holiday pay is $4-$6 an hour extra depending on your position, not 1.5x or 2x pay here.
-Favoritism in management.
-Constant revolving door, seems like the new RNs that are good leave within a few months, and the lazy ones gain seniority.
-Rules are bent depending on who you are or who you know.

review_title: I want to come back and work for ACH, but won't make enough money

pros: Great communication from upper management, good teamwork atmosphere, easy to use computer systems for paperwork. Great benefits. Good opportunities to transfer to other centers, pick up extra work as enhanced compensations.
cons: Lower pay than surrounding areas in working with pediatrics. If you work at a satellite center, you miss out on a lot of the happenings at the main hospital. Tend to feel like you aren't a part of the entire system sometimes. They have special parties and events for the main hospital staff and they rarely do events for the satellite centers...I think once a year.
